coredata.dc:title: The reorganization energies in one-electron oxidation of ferrous complexes in aqueous solution
coredata.dc:creator: Ono, Kaori
Watanabe, Iwao
Ikeda, Shigero
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The photoelectron emission method was used to determine the reorganization free energy of nuclear coordinates in one-electron oxidation reactions. The experimental results for eight ferrous complexes, some of which have large organic ligands, in aqueous solution are in excellent agreement with the theoretical ones.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 128, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 July 1986 THE REORGANIZATION ENERGIES IN ONE-ELECTRON OXIDATION OF FERROUS COMPLEXES IN AQUEOUS SOLUTION Kaori ONO, Iwao WATANABE and Shigero IKEDA Department of Chemistry, Osaka University, Toyonaka, Osaka 560, Japan Received 3 March 1986; in final form 13 May 1986 The photoelectron emission method was used to determine the reorganization free energy of nuclear coordinates in one-electron oxidation reactions. The experimental results for eight ferrous complexes, some of which have large organic ligands, in aqueous solution are in excellent agreement with the theoretical ones. 1. Introduction The reorganization of nuclear coordinates is very important in electron-transfer reactions, for which many kinetic and theoretical studies have been made [1-9]. Recently, the free energies of reorganization AG^ have been determined from photoelectron emission data and compared with theoretical values [10 12]. However, the reported photoelectron emission data do not cover various kinds of complexes which would permit further evaluation of the validity of the tech- nique and the theory. Therefore we measured photo- electron emission from several ferrous complexes with large ligands to obtain the reorganization energies in aqueous solution and compared them with the theo- retical ones. 2. Experimental The ferrous complexes, [Fe(phen)3]2+, [FeO^]^, [Fe(dmbpy)3]2+, [FeQn^]^ and [Fe(tpy)2]2"1", were all prepared as aqueous solutions with SO2" as a counter anion. Only [Fe(edta)]2- was treated under nitrogen atmosphere. For [Fe(aq)g ]2+ and [Fe(CN)g]4-, solutions ofFeS04-7H20 and K4 [Fe(CN)g], respectively, were used. The pH value of each solution was adjusted, if necessary, so that it might be optimum for the formation of complexes [13]. 0 009-2614/86/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Divison) The abbreviations used in this paper are: phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine, dmbpy = 4,4'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridine, tmp = 3,4,7,8-tetra- methyl-1,10-phenanthroline, tpy = 2,2':6',6"-ter- pyridine, edta = ethylenediamine-N,N,N',N'-tetra- acetate, aq = water, CN = cyanide. Measurements of photoelectron emission were carried out at 1 C with the apparatus in our laboratory [14]. The free energy^ for photoelectron emission was determined according to the extrapolation method (n = 2) [14]. Dispersion corrections to E^ values were not applied, since the correction is considered to be small [10]. Each standard redox potential E was mea- sured by cyclic voltametry as for [Fe(phen)3]2+, [FeC^]^, ^(dmbpy),]^, [FeC^]^ and [Fettpy)^]2'1'. These were in agreement with the published values [15], except for [Fe(dmbpy)3]2"1", for which the E values have not previously been re- ported. 3. Results Following Delahay and Dziedzic [10], the free energy for emission E^ is expressed as ^=-AG +AGh+AG,+|e|Ax, (1) where AG^ (= 4.5 eV *) and AG (= -nFE ) are the ' For footnote see next page. 287 Volume 128, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 28 July 1986 free energies for the reactions ^Hl(E)=Hlso]v)+e(g ) (2) and [Fe(III)L](^)-4H2(g) =[Fe(II)L](^)+H^, (3) respectively. [Fe(III)L] and [Fe(II)L] represent ferric and ferrous species, respectively. The charge and the number of ligands in the complexes are omitted for simplicity. The subscript (solv) means solvation by water. \e\A\ is the term for the surface potential, which is negligibly small (<0.05 eV) [10]. AG';. is the free energy of reorganization of nuclear coordinates, which can be calculated theoretically as ^G,=R^+R^, (4) where-Rjn and^p^ are the free energies of inner- and outer-sphere reorganizations and are given by ^=^W)2, (5) R^-^We^-e,1), (6) * We consider that 4.5 eV due to Noyes [16] can be used here, since the accuracy of the photoelectron emission method is of the order of 0.1 eV. More accurate values have been quoted by Delahay and Dziedzic [10] (4.48 0.06 eV) and by Parsons [17] (4.44 0.05 eV). phen bpy dmbpy edta CN tpy tmp *.^ --* -'" " ' 6.0 8.0 7.0 hV / eV Fig. 1. Photoelectron emission spectra of a series of Fe2* complexes. Y is the photoelectron emission yield. where N is the coordination number of the complex, which is 6 in the present study, /g the force constant for the bond between the ferric ion and the ligand L, Ar the change in the metal ligand distance r upon oxidation, e is the charge of an electron, a the mean radius of the assumed boundaries between inner- and outer-sphere regions for ferric and ferrous complexes, and eg? and e, the optical and static dielectric con- stants of water. Fig. 1 shows the photoelectron emission spectra obtained for eight ferrous complexes. The experi- mentally determined free energies for emission are listed in table 1. Table 1 Calculated and experimental free energies for photoelectron emission, experimentally estimated reorganization energies and structural data nFE (eV) Ar (A) a (A) Kin (eV) Rout (eV) ^alc (eV) -,exp (eV) AG,?^ (eV) Fe(edta)2' 0.117 (5.47)1') (0.72) 7.06 2.44 Fe(CN)r 0.36 0.01 a) 4.560) 0.01 0.86 5.73 5.60 0.74 Fe(aq)F 0.77 0.13 a) 3.90'3) 0.81 1.01 7.09 7.09 1.82 Feftmp)^ 0.832 0.00 8.38 0.00 0.47 5.80 5.73 0.40 Fe(dmbpy)J'1' 0.905 0.00 7.29 0.00 0.54 5.95 6.12 0.72 Fe(phen)r 1.056 0.00 7.35 e) 0.00 0.54 6.10 6.14 0.58 Feftpy)2* 1.062 0.00 5.910 0.00 0.64 6.20 6.05 0.49 Feftpy)2* 1.085 0.00 6.978) 0.00 0.57 6.16 6.15 0.57 a) Ref. [2]. b) Ref. (20]. c) Refs. [2,21]. d) Refs. [2,22,23]. e) Refs. [2,24,25]. 0 Ref. [26]. S) Ref. [27]. 288 Volume 128, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 July 1986 The ^xp values from the present experiment for ^(acOe]2-*- and [Fe(CN)g]4- differ a little from the ones reported most recently (7.30 and 6.2 eV respectively) [10]. The present^1' value for [Fe(aq)g]2+ is lower than the one determined by Delahay and Dziedzic by about 0.2 eV. This might be due to uncertainty in the extrapolation method, i.e. which energy region should be chosen for anal- ysis. The value for [Fe^I^g]4" agrees with the first one by the same authors (5.60 eV) [18]. Later they revised the value to 6.2 eV [10], considering the autoionization process. It seems that the higher E^ value cannot be justified from the present results for some ferrous complexes. The spectra for the com- plexes with phen, bpy, tmp and dmbpy have shoulders and they pertain to the bound-to-bound state tran- sition and the autoionization process. No reasonable results can be obtained for these complexes, using the higher E^ values determined from the region after autoionization. It has been reported, for ferrocene, that the autoionization process is not important in determining theE^ value in the threshold region [19]. To estimate the value of ^ by eq. (1), both/?^ and Ry^ must be calculated according to eqs. (5) and (6). The values r and a for ferrous and ferric com- plexes have been determined by X-ray diffraction and EXAFS studies [20-27]. Since there is no dif- ference in the value of r regardless of the charge for [Fe(phen)3]2+/3+ or [Fe(bpy)3]2+/3+, the value of Ar should be negligibly small for these complexes and others with analogous ligands. Hence R^ = 0 for them. The theoretically calculated values E^ are included in table 1. The^t value for [^(CN)^]4- agrees with that calculated by Delahay and Dziedzic but that for [Fe(aq)g]2"1" is smaller than theirs by 0.13 eV, because a different estimation of the radius a is used here as follows: ' Fe-X+rX' (7) where dpg_x is the distance between the central iron atom and the atom X at the most distant position from the iron in the ligand, and r^ the van der Waals radius of X. As shown in fig. 2,Eak: agrees excellently with E^9. Hence we make an attempt to evaluate AG^, the experimentally estimated reorganization energy, by comparing E^P with AG10. 70 Caq phen,-' dmbpy^ ^bw o. 6.0 x <L*- UJ /' tpy ^tmp /2CN 50 7.0 60 ccalc / eV Fig. 2. Correlation of experimental and calculated free energy for photoelectron emission by aqueous solutions of Fe2 complexes. The interrupted line shows the ideal cor- relation. It is readily seen that the values of AG^ for [Fe(aq)g ]2+ and [Fe(edta)]2- are considerably larger than those for the others. It can be attributed to the large contribution of the inner-sphere reorganization in the case of [Fe(aq)g]2'1". Although the calculation ofAG;. for [Fe(edta)]2" is impossible because of the lack of structural data, one can conclude that the inner-sphere reorganization for [Fe(edta)]2- is very large ( L7 eV), when/?^ is estimated approximately by using the crystallographic [Fe(edta)]" radius. As a conclusion, this work strongly supports the photoelectron emission method in considering the reorganization energy intrinsic to electron-transfer reactions. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The photoelectron emission method was used to determine the reorganization free energy of nuclear coordinates in one-electron oxidation reactions. The experimental results for eight ferrous complexes, some of which have large organic ligands, in aqueous solution are in excellent agreement with the theoretical ones.
